<h2>Progreso y retroceso social en el sureste mexicano</h2>

<h3><span style='color:#4f4f4f'>[Social Progress and Regression in the Mexican Southeast]</span></h3>
 

* The text discusses the limitations of using economic indicators such as GDP per capita to evaluate the quality of life in a specific region, specifically the southeast region of Mexico, which is made up of the states of Oaxaca, Chiapas and Guerrero.
* It argues that to have a more complete understanding of the quality of life in each region, it is necessary to examine the economic situation of the region and complement it with measurements focused on evaluating human development such as the <a href="https://github.com/mexicocomovamos/ips">IPS (Social Progress Index)</a> of Mexico.
* This analysis was carried out using R to process the IPS data and generate the visualizations.

<h2>Centralización administrativa y carnicería institucional</h2>

<h3><span style='color:#4f4f4f'>[Administrative Centralization and Institutional Carnage]</span></h3>
 

* This article analyzes the consequences of the law amendment to disappear 17 Mexican government agencies under the argument of austerity.
* This reform must be understood as a centralization process because, after analyzing the open data of the budget, it is shown that the savings from disappearing these institutions would be minimal.
* To carry out this research, data from the open budget of Mexico were processed and visualized with {tidyverse} package.
* This text was among the <a href="https://anticorrupcion.nexos.com.mx/los-10-textos-mas-leidos-del-ano-4/">ten most read in 2022</a> on the Nexos' anti-corruption blog.

<h2>Militarización de la seguridad pública: La confianza es la madre del descuido</h2>

<h3><span style='color:#4f4f4f'>[Militarization of Public Security: Trust is the Cause of Carelessness]</span></h3>
 

* The text discusses the causes and consequences of the military’s involvement in public security activities.
* It is found that the more the trust gap between the military and the police grows, in a context of high levels of insecurity, the more the military is called upon to address public security issues. Consequently, the more the population trusts the military, the more likely they are to commit human rights violations.
* The study models data from 15 Latin American countries between 1995 and 2015 and 17 countries in the region between 2004 and 2013 using R and Stata.

<h2>Militarización, militarismo y corrupción</h2>

<h3><span style='color:#4f4f4f'>[Militarization, Militarism and Corruption]</span></h3>
 

* This chapter analyzes the opinion of Mexicans regarding the growing participation of the military in civilian tasks and the effects on the level of corruption.
* It was found that a significant portion of the population perceives the military as one of the least corrupt institutions, leading to high support for militarization policies. However, this has not led to a lesser perception of corruption in projects conducted by the army.
* It could have consequences for the democratic process and the balance of power between civilian and military institutions
* To obtain these results, a face-to-face survey of 1,500 people was designed, conducted, and analyzed with {srvyr}.

<h2>Ley de Ingresos 2023: deuda billonaria histórica y supuestos poco creíbles</h2>

<h3><span style='color:#4f4f4f'>[2023 Revenues Plan: national debt and hardly credible assumptions]</span></h3>
 

* This article analyzes Mexico's public revenue plan for 2023.
* It is expected to be the highest amount of expenditure of which there is record, along with a level of indebtedness that had not been observed in a decade (1.2 trillion pesos). However, macroeconomic projections indicate that next year's revenues could be below the plan, which could seriously compromise the compliance of 2023 expenditure goals.
* These results were found after processing the open data of public finances and the maroeconomic expectations of the central bank of Mexico and other international institutions..
